g5302.definition: [ὑστερέω] from {{g5306}}; to be later, i.e. (by implication) to be inferior; generally, to fall short (be deficient)

g5304.definition: [ὑστέρησις] from {{g5302}}; a falling short, i.e. (specially), penury

g5305.definition: [ὕστερον] neuter of {{g5306}} as adverb; more lately, i.e. eventually

g5306.definition: [ὕστερος] comparative from {{g5259}} (in the sense of behind); later

g5307.definition: [ὑφαντός] from ὑφαίνω to weave; woven, i.e. (perhaps) knitted

g5309.definition: [ὑψηλοφρονέω] from a compound of {{g5308}} and {{g5424}}; to be lofty in mind, i.e. arrogant

g5310.definition: [ὕψιστος] superlative from the base of {{g5311}}; highest, i.e. (masculine singular) the Supreme (God), or (neuter plural) the heavens

g5311.definition: [ὕψος] from a derivative of {{g5228}}; elevation, i.e. (abstractly) altitude, (specially), the sky, or (figuratively) dignity

g5313.definition: [ὕψωμα] from {{g5312}}; an elevated place or thing, i.e. (abstractly) altitude, or (by implication) a barrier (figuratively)

g5315.definition: [φάγω] a primary verb (used as an alternate of {{g2068}} in certain tenses); to eat (literally or figuratively)

g5316.definition: [φαίνω] prolongation for the base of {{g5457}}; to lighten (shine), i.e. show (transitive or intransitive, literal or figurative)

g5317.definition: [Φάλεκ] of Hebrew origin ({{h6389}}); Phalek (i.e. Peleg), a patriarch

g5318.definition: [φανερός] from {{g5316}}; shining, i.e. apparent (literally or figuratively); neuter (as adverb) publicly, externally

g5319.definition: [φανερόω] from {{g5318}}; to render apparent (literally or figuratively)

g5320.definition: [φανερῶς] adverb from {{g5318}}; plainly, i.e. clearly or publicly

g5321.definition: [φανέρωσις] from {{g5319}}; exhibition, i.e. (figuratively) expression, (by extension) a bestowment

g5322.definition: [φανός] from {{g5316}}; a lightener, i.e. light; lantern

g5323.definition: [Φανουήλ] of Hebrew origin ({{h6439}}); Phanuel (i.e. Penuel), an Israelite

g5324.definition: [φαντάζω] from a derivative of {{g5316}}; to make apparent, i.e. (passively) to appear (neuter participle as noun, a spectacle)

g5325.definition: [φαντασία] from a derivative of {{g5324}}; (properly abstract) a (vain) show ("fantasy")

g5326.definition: [φάντασμα] from {{g5324}}; (properly concrete) a (mere) show ("phantasm"), i.e. spectre

g5327.definition: [φάραγξ] properly, strengthened from the base of {{g4008}} or rather of {{g4486}}; a gap or chasm, i.e. ravine (winter-torrent)

g5328.definition: [Φαραώ] of foreign origin ({{h6547}}); Pharao (i.e. Pharoh), an Egyptian king

g5329.definition: [Φάρες] of Hebrew origin ({{h6557}}); Phares (i.e. Perets), an Israelite

g5330.definition: [Φαρισαῖος] of Hebrew origin (compare {{h6567}}); a separatist, i.e. exclusively religious; a Pharisean, i.e. Jewish sectary

g5331.definition: [φαρμακεία] from {{g5332}}; medication ("pharmacy"), i.e. (by extension) magic (literally or figuratively)

g5332.definition: [φαρμακεύς] from φάρμακον (a drug, i.e. spell-giving potion); a druggist ("pharmacist") or poisoner, i.e. (by extension) a magician

g5334.definition: [φάσις] from {{g5346}} (not the same as "phase", which is from {{g5316}}); a saying, i.e. report

g5335.definition: [φάσκω] prolongation from the same as {{g5346}}; to assert

g5336.definition: [φάτνη] from πατέομαι (to eat); a crib (for fodder)

g5337.definition: [φαῦλος] apparently a primary word; "foul" or "flawy", i.e. (figuratively) wicked

g5338.definition: [φέγγος] probably akin to the base of {{g5457}} (compare {{g5350}}); brilliancy

g5339.definition: [φείδομαι] of uncertain affinity; to be chary of, i.e. (subjectively) to abstain or (objectively) to treat leniently

g5340.definition: [φειδομένως] adverb from participle of {{g5339}}; abstemiously, i.e. stingily

g5341.definition: [φελόνης] by transposition for a derivative probably of {{g5316}} (as showing outside the other garments); a mantle (surtout)

g5342.definition: [φέρω] a primary verb (for which other, and apparently not cognate ones are used in certain tenses only; namely,          οἴω;       and ἐνέγκω; to "bear" or carry (in a very wide application, literally and figuratively, as follows)

g5343.definition: [φεύγω] apparently a primary verb; to run away (literally or figuratively); by implication, to shun; by analogy, to vanish

g5344.definition: [Φῆλιξ] of Latin origin; happy; Phelix (i.e. Felix), a Roman

g5346.definition: [φημί] properly, the same as the base of {{g5457}} and {{g5316}}; to show or make known one's thoughts, i.e. speak or say Compare {{g3004}}.

g5347.definition: [Φῆστος] of Latin derivation; festal; Phestus (i.e. Festus), a Roman

g5348.definition: [φθάνω] apparently a primary verb; to be beforehand, i.e. anticipate or precede; by extension, to have arrived at

g5350.definition: [φθέγγομαι] probably akin to {{g5338}} and thus to {{g5346}}; to utter a clear sound, i.e. (generally) to proclaim

g5351.definition: [φθείρω] probably strengthened from φθίω (to pine or waste); properly, to shrivel or wither, i.e. to spoil (by any process) or (generally) to ruin (especially figuratively, by moral influences, to deprave)

g5352.definition: [φθινοπωρινός] from derivative of φθίνω  (to wane; akin to the base of {{g5351}}) and {{g3703}} (meaning late autumn); autumnal (as stripped of leaves)

g5353.definition: [φθόγγος] from {{g5350}}; utterance, i.e. a musical note (vocal or instrumental)

g5355.definition: [φθόνος] probably akin to the base of {{g5351}}; ill-will (as detraction), i.e. jealousy (spite)

g5356.definition: [φθορά] from {{g5351}}; decay, i.e. ruin (spontaneous or inflicted, literally or figuratively)

g5357.definition: [φιάλη] of uncertain affinity; a broad shallow cup ("phial")

g5358.definition: [φιλάγαθος] from {{g5384}} and {{g18}}; fond to good, i.e. a promoter of virtue

g5359.definition: [Φιλαδέλφεια] from Φιλάδελφος (the same as {{g5361}}), a king of Pergamos; Philadelphia, a place in Asia Minor

g5361.definition: [φιλάδελφος] from {{g5384}} and {{g80}}; fond of brethren, i.e. fraternal

g5362.definition: [φίλανδρος] from {{g5384}} and {{g435}}; fond of man, i.e. affectionate as a wife

g5363.definition: [φιλανθρωπία] from the same as {{g5364}}; fondness of mankind, i.e. benevolence ("philanthropy")

g5364.definition: [φιλανθρώπως] adverb from a compound of {{g5384}} and {{g444}}; fondly to man ("philanthropically"), i.e. humanely

g5366.definition: [φιλάργυρος] from {{g5384}} and {{g696}}; fond of silver (money), i.e. avaricious

g5367.definition: [φίλαυτος] from {{g5384}} and {{g846}}; fond of self, i.e. selfish

g5368.definition: [φιλέω] from {{g5384}}; to be a friend to (fond of (an individual or an object)), i.e. have affection for (denoting personal attachment, as a matter of sentiment or feeling; while {{g25}} is wider, embracing especially the judgment and the deliberate assent of the will as a matter of principle, duty and propriety: the two thus stand related very much as {{g2309}} and {{g1014}}, or as {{g2372}} and {{g3563}} respectively; the former being chiefly of the heart and the latter of the head); specially, to kiss (as a mark of tenderness)

g5369.definition: [φιλήδονος] from {{g5384}} and {{g2237}}; fond of pleasure, i.e. voluptuous

g5372.definition: [Φίλητος] from {{g5368}}; amiable; Philetus, an opposer of Christianity

g5374.definition: [Φιλιππήσιος] from {{g5375}}; a Philippesian (Philippian), i.e. native of Philippi

g5375.definition: [Φίλιπποι] plural of {{g5376}}; Philippi, a place in Macedonia

g5376.definition: [Φίλιππος] from {{g5384}} and {{g2462}}; fond of horses; Philippus, the name of four Israelites

g5377.definition: [φιλόθεος] from {{g5384}} and {{g2316}}; fond of God, i.e. pious

g5378.definition: [Φιλόλογος] from {{g5384}} and {{g3056}}; fond of words, i.e. talkative (argumentative, learned, "philological"); Philologus, a Christian

g5380.definition: [φιλόνεικος] from {{g5384}} and νεῖκος (a quarrel; probably akin to {{g3534}}); fond of strife, i.e. disputatious

g5382.definition: [φιλόξενος] from {{g5384}} and {{g3581}}; fond of guests, i.e. hospitable

g5383.definition: [φιλοπρωτεύω] from a compound of {{g5384}} and {{g4413}}; to be fond of being first, i.e. ambitious of distinction

g5384.definition: [φίλος] properly, dear, i.e. a friend; actively, fond, i.e. friendly (still as a noun, an associate, neighbor, etc.)

g5386.definition: [φιλόσοφος] from {{g5384}} and {{g4680}}; fond of wise things, i.e. a "philosopher"

g5387.definition: [φιλόστοργος] from {{g5384}} and στοργή (cherishing one's kindred, especially parents or children); fond of natural relatives, i.e. fraternal towards fellow Christian

g5388.definition: [φιλότεκνος] from {{g5384}} and {{g5043}}; fond of one's children, i.e. maternal

g5389.definition: [φιλοτιμέομαι] middle voice from a compound of {{g5384}} and {{g5092}}; to be fond of honor, i.e. emulous (eager or earnest to do something)

g5390.definition: [φιλοφρόνως] adverb from {{g5391}}; with friendliness of mind, i.e. kindly

g5391.definition: [φιλόφρων] from {{g5384}} and {{g5424}}; friendly of mind, i.e. kind

g5393.definition: [Φλέγων] active participle of the base of {{g5395}}; blazing; Phlegon, a Christian

g5394.definition: [φλογίζω] from {{g5395}}; to cause a blaze, i.e. ignite (figuratively, to inflame with passion)

g5395.definition: [φλόξ] from a primary φλέγω (to "flash" or "flame"); a blaze

g5396.definition: [φλυαρέω] from {{g5397}}; to be a babbler or trifler, i.e. (by implication) to berate idly or mischievously

g5397.definition: [φλύαρος] from φλύω (to bubble); a garrulous person, i.e. prater

g5399.definition: [φοβέω] from {{g5401}}; to frighten, i.e. (passively) to be alarmed; by analogy, to be in awe of, i.e. revere

g5400.definition: [φόβητρον] neuter of a derivative of {{g5399}}; a frightening thing, i.e. terrific portent
